Study: COVID-19 herd immunity strategies: walking an elusive and dangerous tightrope
Factors: school and university closure
Excerpt: The addition of school (and university) closures, corresponding to a 70% reduction in contacts among school-aged individuals and a 20% reduction with 25-59 year-olds, dramatically reduces the rate of epidemic growth
Measure of Evidence: Countries: The UK; Timeline: -

Study: Modeling the COVID-19 epidemic in Okinawa
Factors: School closure
Excerpt: We find that an R0 close to 2.5 provides a good fit of rate of increase in the number of hospitalized case as a function of time; Rt median suppression: 6%
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Japan; Timeline: March 15th 2020 - April 15th

Study: Estimating the impact of non-pharmaceutical interventions on documented infections with COVID-19: A cross-country analysis medrxiv
Factors: closure of schools (for primary schools and/or attendance rates below ~10%)
Excerpt: School closures yield a reduction of only 11 % (95% CrI 0–27 %) and its relative impact is one of the lowest among the various policy measures considered in this analysis
Measure of Evidence: Countries: United States, Canada, Australia, the EU-15 countries, Norway, and Switzerland; Timeline:  April 15, 2020

Study: Modelling transmission and control of the COVID-19 pandemic in Australia
Factors: School closure
Excerpt: The scale of the impact is very high, with nearly 50% of the Australian population showing symptoms. This baseline scenario is provided only for comparison, in order to evaluate the impact of interventions, most of which are already in place in Australia. To re-iterate, we consider timely intervention scenarios applicable to the situation in Australia at the end of March 2020, in which the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases crossed 2,000 on 24 March 2020, and the growth rate of cumulative incidence C˙ stayed above 20% for nearly two weeks prior to that. We observe that the simulated baseline generates the 20% cumulative incidence increase, in a strong agreement with actual dynamics.; In short, the only tangible benefit of school closures, coupled with case isolation and home quarantine, is in delaying the epidemic peak by four weeks, at the expense of a slight increase in the contribution of children to the incidence peak. Given other societal costs of school closures (e.g., drawing their parents employed in healthcare and other critical infrastructure away from work), this strategy may be less effective
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Australia ;Timeline: 49 days

Study: Can the COVID-19 epidemic be controlled on the basis of daily test reports?
Factors: schools and further education institutions closed
Excerpt: R0 = 4 ;Given the estimates of R0, a reduction by at least 60-70% or more is necessary to suppress exponential growth. The main result of [7] is that lockdown leads to an average reduction of Rt by 50% school closure by 20%, other measures around 10%
Measure of Evidence: Countries: -: Newcastle; -
